Description: A pottery jar-lid modelled as fish in a dish. Four dead and well-modelled fishes (Tilapia sp., perhaps nilotica), two placed head to tail on top of and at right-angles to two similar fish resting in a dish, their heads and tails overlapping its rim. Details are shown on the underside, where the heads and tails project over the edge of the dish. The dish is circular and has a plain convex underside; its rim nested into the mouth of the jar it covered. Hand-modelled and solid, with incised detail of scales and fins. Micaceous brown Nile silt.
Curator's comments: Published: Sale Catalogue Galerie Nefer 6 (1988), Zurich, no.61. Burnham's Catalogue 29 (April 1991) lot 328. JEA 79 (1993), p.239. Museum acquisitions 199, Eleni Vassililla.

Terracotta IV Purchased. Gustav Moustaki Collection. Probably Ptolemaic, but it could as easily be Pharaonic. Comparandum: Not unlike a much smaller bone lid, decorated with two similar fishes: Christie's South Kensington Sale Catalogue, 28 April 2004: lot: 362. Bibliog: Galerie Nefer Sale Catalogue 6 (1988): lot 61; Bonham's Sale Catalogue, 29 April 1991: lot 328; Ede n.d.b: x, lot 45; Vassilika 1993: 239, no. 38.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3745)
Neumark 1991 / Selected Acquisitions: May to July (p.25)
Condition: Good. Extremities of fish slightly chipped.
